Graphical abstract This review aims to summarize the recent research progress of PBI membranes in lithium batteries and promote a comprehensive and systematic understanding of this field. With the rapid development of portable technology, lithium batteries have emerged as potential candidates for high-performance energy storage systems owing to their high energy density and cycling stability. Among the key components of a lithium battery system, the separator plays a critical role as it directly influences the battery performance benchmark (cycling performance and safety). However, traditional polyolefin separators (polypropylene/polyethylene) are unable to meet the demands of high-performance and safer battery systems due to their poor electrolyte compatibility, thermal runaways, and ultimate growth of dendrites. In contrast, membranes fabricated using polybenzimidazole (PBI) exhibit excellent electrolyte wettability and outstanding thermal dimensional stability, thus holding great potential as separators for high-performance and high-safety batteries. In this paper, we present a comprehensive review of the general requirements for separators, synthesis technology for separators, and research trends focusing PBI membranes in lithium batteries to alleviate the current commercial challenges faced by conventional polyolefin separators. In addition, we discuss the future development direction for PBI battery separators by considering various factors such as production cost, ecological footprint, preparation technology, and battery component compatibility. By exploring these perspectives, we aim to promote the continued application and exploration of PBI-based materials to advance lithium battery technology. Keywords Lithium batteries Separators Porous separators Polybenzimidazole Membrane 1 Introduction Driven by the rapid development of the third industrial revolution, the demand for energy is continuously rising and may further affect the energy supply chain. Conventional fossil fuel resources (oil, natural gas, etc.) are being depleted continuously and cannot meet up the world's energy demands anymore. In addition to this, secondary pollution offered by conventional fossil fuels may severely affect the sustainability of the system, which is also a significant barrier to further advancement [1–5]. Consequently, there is a strong consensus among stakeholders to explore energy storage solutions using green and sustainable technologies. Among various energy storage systems, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have emerged as one of the most efficient and promising options. They offer high energy density, extended cycle life, and minimal self-discharge, making them highly desirable for a wide range of applications (portable electronic devices, electric vehicles, and smart electricity systems) [6–11]. The traditional LIB is primarily composed of four components: anode, cathode, separator, and electrolyte. During the charging process, lithium ions are transferred from the cathode and embedded into the anode through the electrolyte and separator, and the process is reversed during discharge [12,13]. The separator is an electronic insulating layer, effectively preventing direct contact between the anode and cathode and facilitating the transfer of lithium ions. Although the separator itself does not actively participant in the electrochemical processes in the battery, its physical and chemical properties have a significant influence on the battery performance in terms of cycle stability and safety. An ideal separator should possess several characteristics, including good chemical stability, excellent wettability, high ionic conductivity, strong mechanical properties, and superior thermal stability. Currently, commercial LIB separators are mainly made from polyolefin materials, such as polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP). These polyolefin separators exhibit excellent mechanical properties and electrochemical stability while being cost-effective. However, their inherent poor thermal stability (the melting points of PE and PP are 130 and 160 °C, respectively) and poor wettability to carbonate-based electrolytes result in low ionic conductivity, limiting their application in high-performance energy systems [14–17]. Moreover, the poor interfacial compatibility between the polyolefin separator and the electrodes can lead to the formation of an unstable solid electrolyte interfacial (SEI) layer. This condition increases the risk of uneven lithium dendrite growth, resulting in short circuits and ultimate battery failure [18–23]. Therefore, the development of novel and stable separator materials is necessary to address these challenges for safer energy storage options. Polybenzimidazole (PBI) is an aromatic polymer with excellent chemical stability, ultra-high thermal stability (up to 400 °C), inherent flame retardancy, and exceptional mechanical properties [24,25]. These remarkable characteristics have led to its widespread usage in various industries (Fig. 1 ), such as protective clothing, automobiles, and aviation sectors [26–29]. With the rising interest in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) in the 1990s, acid-doped polybenzimidazole with favorable proton conductivity garnered significant attention from researchers [30]. Since then, PBI has become a prominent research area in the realm of proton exchange separators in energy storage systems [31–34]. The outstanding physical and chemical properties of PBI and its derivatives, such as poly-(arylene ether benzimidazole) (OPBI), have encouraged researchers to explore its applications in battery separators through various preparation methods, such as phase conversion, particle leaching, and electrospinning [35–37]. However, more hands-on researches are further needed to advance these membranes for more reliable battery systems including lithium-metal batteries (LMBs), lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs), and solid-state batteries (SSBs). In this paper, we present a comprehensive review of the recent progress on Li batteries utilizing PBI separators, as demonstrated in Fig. 2 . We begin by outlining the essential requirements of separators for lithium batteries. Subsequently, we discuss the widely employed preparation technologies for fabricating different types of separators. The focus then shifts to the specific application of PBI and its derivatives in Li batteries, including LMBs, LSBs, and SSBs. Specifically, we thoroughly examine the separator preparation methods and characteristics to elucidate the functionalities enabled by PBI-based separators and their associated challenges for energy storage systems. Additionally, this review presents perspective on the future development of PBI separators in Li batteries to offer more insights in ongoing progress and application of PBI separators for Li batteries. 2 General requirements on separators for lithium batteries As an insulator between anode and cathode, the separators are required to avoid short circuits and ensure free transmission of ions on both sides. Although the battery separator is not an active component, its physical and chemical properties significantly affect the electrochemical performance of batteries. In this section, we highlight fundamental requirements for separators used in Li batteries. 2.1 Chemical and electrochemical stability In order to ensure the stability and safety of battery performance, the separator must possess excellent chemical stability, effectively preventing degradation caused by the electrolyte or electrode. Ideally, the dry separator should maintain an electrochemical window above 0 V and exceed 5 V vs. Li+/Li. 2.2 Electrolyte wettability and ionic conductivity The ideal separator should have good electrolyte wettability and storage capacity to guarantee low internal resistance and high ionic conductivity. The wettability of a separator is predominantly influenced by the material chemical characteristics, porosity, tortuosity, and the type of electrolyte utilized. In general, the wettability of the separator is evaluated by measuring the content of electrolytes stored in the separator after soaking it in liquid electrolytes for 24 h. The specific calculation formula is as follows. EU ( % ) = W w e t - W d r y W d r y × 100 % where W dry and W wet are the relative weights of the separator before and after being submerged in the electrolyte. We can also evaluate the wettability by measuring the dynamic contact angle of the separator. A smaller contact angle and faster entry of the electrolyte into the separator indicate better wettability, showcasing the ability of the separator to interact favorably with the electrolyte. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is employed to measure the resistance (R b) of the separator by assembling the stainless-steel (SS) symmetric cell (SS/separator/SS) with the electrolyte-soaked separator sandwiched in-between. The ionic conductivity (σ) is determined according to the following formula. σ = d R b × S Here d is the thickness and S is the effective area of the separator. 2.3 Pore size and distribution As an insulator, the separator also requires an appropriate pore size to fulfill two crucial functions: preventing the penetration of electrode material particles and facilitating the passage of lithium ions. While a smaller pore size might reduce current leakage, it could potentially increase ion transport resistance; generally, the pore size in the sub-micron range (<1 µm) can reduce the risk of internal short-circuiting while providing a good battery performance [38–40]. Furthermore, the pore distribution of the separator plays a critical role. A uniform pore distribution ensures a consistent current density. In contrast, an uneven current density may result in issues related to the growth of lithium dendrites, ultimately impacting the battery performance and lifespan [41–45]. The pore size and distribution of the separator can be measured by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), mercury injection porosimetry (MIP) [6], capillary flow porosimetry, or Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). 2.4 Porosity Appropriate porosity can ensure appropriate ionic conductivity. Insufficient porosity can lead to poor electrolyte intake and increased internal resistance. Conversely, excessive porosity can significantly compromise the mechanical properties of the separator, potentially jeopardizing battery safety [46]. The porosity of the separator is defined as the ratio of the pore volume to its apparent geometric volume, and the calculation formula is as follows. Porosity = 1 - ρ m ρ p × 100 % Here, ρ m and ρ p represent the density of the separator and the polymer, respectively. In general, the porosity of the separator can be determined by weighing the mass of the separator before and after the soak of electrolyte and calculating it according to the formula as follows. Porosity = m w e t - m d r y ρ L V 0 × 100 % where the m dry and m wet are the mass of the separator before and after being soaked in the electrolyte, respectively, the ρ L is the density of the liquid electrolyte, and the V 0 is the geometric volume of the separator. 2.5 Thickness and mechanical properties The thickness of a separator is a critical factor for achieving a balance between thickness and high energy density while ensuring safety. Typically, an even thickness of around 20–25 μm is preferred. A thicker separator can lead to higher ionic resistance, occupying a significant internal space within the battery, thus reducing its energy density. On the other hand, a thinner separator may compromise the mechanical strength, raising the potential of internal short circuits. Therefore, it is crucial to minimize the thickness of the separator while ensuring adequate mechanical strength, which can be measured using the American Society for Testing Materials (ASTM) standard method D645/D645M-9. The mechanical properties are key factors for separators, which are mainly affected by factors such as material, thickness, porosity, pore size, and distribution. Appropriate thickness, porosity, pore size, and uniform pore size distribution can ensure the internal continuity and structural stability of the separator, evenly distribute the pressure borne by the separator, and ensure good mechanical properties of the separator. The mechanical properties of the battery separator are characterized by two essential parameters: tensile strength and puncture strength. The separator must have a tensile strength capable of withstanding the tension of the battery assembly. According to ASTM D882 and D638 standards, the minimum tensile strength required for a battery separator with a thickness of 25 µm is 1000 kg cm−2 or 98.06 MPa. In addition, in order to avoid short circuits caused by electrode materials and lithium dendrite growth during the battery operation, the battery separator also needs to have high puncture strength. According to the ASTM D3763-18 standard, the puncture strength of the separator with a thickness of 25 µm should be higher than 300 g. 2.6 Thermal stability The thermal stability of the separator is crucial to the safety of the battery; maintaining the dimensional stability of separator within a certain operating temperature range is the key to avoiding the thermal runaway of battery [47–53]. Generally, the shrinkage of a separator is required to be less than 5% after 60 min at 90 °C, and the calculation formula is as follows. Shrinkage ( % ) = S i - S f S i × 100 % where the S i and S f represent the original and ultimate areas of the separator after heat treatment, respectively. 3 Preparation technology for separator The preparation method of the separator largely determines the physical and chemical properties of the separator. At present, the preparation methods of commercial polyolefin separators are mainly the dry stretching and wet stretching methods [54,55]. For the dry stretching method, polyolefin raw materials are melted at high temperature, extruded, and blown into crystalline polymers. The separator is further stretched after crystallization heat treatment and annealing, and the crystallization interface is peeled off to form a porous structure, which has the characteristics of a simple process and short working time. The wet stretching method involves mixing a high boiling point hydrocarbon liquid or small molecule substance with a polyolefin resin as a pore-forming agent. The mixture is heated to a molten state and then cooled to induce phase separation. The resulting blend is then pressed into thin sheets, which are subsequently stretched in either the longitudinal or biaxial direction. Finally, the remaining pore-forming agent can be removed by extracting with a volatile solvent or directly drying off through evaporation. This process yields lithium battery separators with high porosity and excellent breathability, thereby meeting the high current charging and discharging requirements of the batteries. However, in high-temperature operating environments, the two aforementioned methods often fail to achieve pore closure, leading to safety hazards such as thermal runaway and short circuits. Additionally, the resulting polyolefin separators are characterized by poor electrolyte wettability and low lithium-ion conductivity, which ultimately limit the performance of the battery. Apart from the two methods discussed above, there are specific preparation methods that can be employed to improve the properties (such as pore size, pore size distribution, mechanical properties, and thermal stability) of the separator, ultimately affecting the performance of the battery in question. In this section, some common processing techniques for the preparation of Li battery separators are described (Fig. 3 ), and the comparison of various techniques is shown in Table 1 . 3.1 Thermally induced phase separation At present, the most prevalent method for the manufacturing process of porous polymer separators is the phase conversion method, which includes thermally induced phase separation (TIPS) [56–60], non-solvent induced phase separation (NIPS) [61–64], and vapor induced phase separation (VIPS) [65–69]. TIPS was first proposed by Castro in the early 1980s. Specifically, it involves dissolving the polymer in a solvent with a high boiling point and low volatility, creating a homogeneous solution at high temperatures. After coating the solution onto a substrate and rapidly cooling it, a phase separation phenomenon occurs in the system (solid-liquid phase separation and liquid-liquid phase separation). Finally, by extracting the solvent using a suitable extractant, a porous polymer separator with a specific structural shape is obtained. The polymer separator prepared by TIPS has excellent mechanical properties and porous structure. The whole process involves only two reactants: solvent and polymer; the binary diagram (polymer-solvent) can predict the pore structure of the separator, and its influencing factors are easy to control. This method has high reproducibility and is easy to achieve continuous production [70]. 3.2 Nonsolvent-induced phase separation NIPS is a commonly used method for preparing separators with asymmetric porous structures characterized by a wide pore size distribution. Different from the TIPS method, NIPS process involves three factors: polymer, solvent, and non-solvent. Specifically, at room temperature, the polymer is dissolved in a suitable solvent to form a homogeneous solution, which is then coated onto a substrate to create a film. The film is then immersed in a specified non-solvent bath, known as the coagulation bath. The chemical potential gradient change caused by the difference in solubility of the polymer in solvent and non-solvent leads to the exchange between solvent and non-solvent. This exchange triggers phase separation and phase inversion, ultimately resulting in the formation of a microporous structure. Similar to TIPS method, this method can predict the phase transition path by a ternary diagram (polymer, solvent, and non-solvent). By adjusting the relationship among these components, the morphology of the separator can be precisely controlled, making NIPS a simple and versatile technique [71]. 3.3 Vapor-induced phase separation VIPS has some similarities with NIPS; the only difference is that the phase conversion process of VIPS does not require the use of a coagulation bath, but the homogeneous solution composed of polymer and solvent is coated into a film and placed in a vapor atmosphere composed of non-solvent, and the vapor penetrates the solution to promote the phase separation. This method greatly reduces the amount of organic solvents used and reduces the manufacturing cost. The separators prepared using VIPS typically exhibit a highly symmetrical porous structure, and the adjustment of pore size and the transition from symmetrical pores to asymmetric pores can be achieved by controlling the relative humidity (RH) of the vapor atmosphere, polymer concentration, and exposure time [69,72]. 3.4 Electrospinning Electrospinning is a technology that can produce polymer solutions into polymer fibers with diameters from 2 μm to 40 nm in a high electric field environment. Specifically, this process involves storing the polymer solution in a capillary tube or pipette and then applying a steadily increasing electric field to it. Once the electric field strength reaches a critical value, the surface tension of the solution is overcome by electrostatic repulsion, leading to the formation of a conical shape at the tip of the capillary (known as the Taylor cone). Subsequently, the polymer solution is ejected from the tip of Taylor cone and deposited onto a collector, where the electric field can control the spray trajectory of the polymer solution. Rapid evaporation of the solvent ensues, resulting in the random distribution of polymer fibers on the collector, ultimately forming a fiber film. The successful production of polymer fibers via electrospinning is influenced by multiple factors, such as the properties of the polymer solution (viscosity, surface tension, electrical conductivity, etc.) and process parameters (electric field strength during spinning, distance between the capillary tip and the collector, etc.). Any alteration of these factors may lead to changes in the overall morphology and properties of the fiber film. Consequently, strict control of these parameters is of utmost importance to achieve desired results [73–78]. 3.5 Particulate leaching The particle leaching method is a commonly employed technique for preparing porous materials, known for its simplicity and cost-effectiveness. Specifically, the process involves dissolving the polymer in an organic solvent and adding a pore-forming template (particles with a specific size, such as water-soluble salt) to the solution. A film is then formed by coating or using a three-dimensional mold, and the solvent is subsequently removed through either evaporation or freeze-drying. Finally, the polymer containing the pore template is placed in a specified solution to dissolve the pore template, resulting in the formation of a porous structure. While the particle leaching method can produce separators with highly porous structures, ensuring interconnectivity and reproducibility of the porous structure can be challenging [79,80]. 4 Application of PBI separator in Li batteries PBI and its derivatives possess excellent high-temperature resistance, flame retardancy, chemical stability, mechanical properties, and strong affinity with electrolytes, making it highly promising for application in lithium battery separators. In this section, we will provide a detailed overview of the unique advantages of PBI and its derivatives as Li battery separators, as well as their distinctive functional characteristics in addressing the challenges faced by Li batteries, such as lithium dendrite growth in LMBs, polysulfide shuttle in LSBs, and low ion conductivity in SSBs. The utilization or incorporation of PBI and its derivatives effectively inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites, suppresses polysulfide shuttle, and enhances the ionic conductivity of solid-state electrolytes. 4.1 Lithium metal batteries At present, most research on the application of PBI in Li batteries focuses on LMBs. According to different compositions and roles, PBI separators can be roughly divided into two types: (1) PBI separators prepared by different methods and (2) PBI-based composite separators. The manufacturing processes and characteristics of these two types of PBI separators will be introduced in the following sections. Furthermore, the inhibition effect of the separator on the growth of lithium dendrite will also be explored. 4.1.1 PBI separators As previously mentioned, the battery separator serves as both a physical barrier to prevent direct contact between the anode and cathode and as a channel for the passage of lithium ions. Therefore, the separator needs to possess a substantial number of open porous structures. In fact, based on the pore structure, the PBI separator can be divided into two sorts: porous and fibrous. The porous PBI separator has continuously connected open pores, which can be obtained by particulate leaching and phase inversion. The fibrous separator is composed of directional or random fibers and contains an integrated framework of PBI fibers, which can be obtained by electrospinning. A summary of characteristics of the PBI separators used in LMBs is shown in Table S1. Li et al. [36] successfully prepared a novel and highly symmetrical spongy porous PBI separator using the water-vapor-induced phase separation. The resulting separator exhibited a remarkable micro-scale pore structure with ultra-thin barriers composed of nanopores, providing ample transport spaces for lithium ions, as illustrated in Fig. 4 (b and c). The prepared separator has extremely high electrolyte wettability, shown in Fig. 4(e) (electrolyte uptake of 328%, contact angle of 9°), which is not only benefited from the unique porous structure and high porosity (81%) of the prepared PBI separator but also due to the strong interaction between the polar nitrogen atoms in the PBI matrix and the electrolyte (Fig. 4a). The high affinity between PBI and the electrolyte also enhances the mechanical properties of the membrane after 24 h of immersion in the electrolyte, resulting in improved tensile strength. The dry film exhibits a tensile strength of 36.41 MPa, while the wet film demonstrates a higher tensile strength of 50.33 MPa. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 4(d), the PBI separator demonstrated ultra-high thermal stability, a crucial factor in ensuring the safety of the battery. This remarkable thermal stability is a result of the rigid structure of PBI and the presence of functional groups along the polymer chain, further reinforcing the suitability of the separator for battery applications. To validate its potential in practical battery systems, the PBI separator was integrated into soft package batteries alongside LiFePO4 cathode and lithium metal anode (Fig. 4f and g). The separator with controllable morphology is crucial for controlling the passage of lithium ions and inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites. The particle leaching method and phase conversion method are the two most commonly used technologies for preparing porous separators with controllable morphology. Liang et al. [81] and Sun et al. [82] prepared a series of OPBI and PBI porous separators with controllable porosity and pore size using environmentally friendly polyethylene glycol (PEG) (Fig. 5 a) and imidazole (Fig. 5c) as pore-forming templates, respectively, and investigated the effect of the mass ratio of PEG to OPBI and imidazole to PBI on porosity and pore size, as well as the performance of the porous separators. Liang et al. investigated the mechanical properties of dense OPBI membranes and porous OPBI membranes prepared with different PEG pore-forming template contents. The dense OPBI membrane displayed excellent mechanical properties with a tensile strength (TS) of 120 MPa and an elongation at break (EB) of 10%. In contrast, the mechanical properties of the other porous membranes were significantly decreased. The porosity and average pore size of the porous OPBI membrane increased with the increasing PEG content in the pore-forming template, leading to a correspondingly inverse trend in mechanical performance. As shown in Fig. 5(b), a large number of spongy interconnecting pores were formed, as the pore-forming template in the dry blend film could be easily removed in water. Additionally, the presence of numerous N–H polar groups in the micropores further facilitated the regulation of Li+ flow transmission and offered a significant number of functional sites, which led to the efficient adsorption and uniform distribution of lithium ions. Both membranes prepared in the study displayed high porosity, high ionic conductivity, excellent thermal stability, and good battery performance. The separator M-4 prepared by Liang et al. using PEG as the pore-forming template showed almost no decay in discharge capacity (150 mA h g−1) after 80 cycles at 1 C current density, which was significantly higher than the commercial Celgard (130 mA h g−1) (Fig. 5d). The separator PBI-3 prepared by Sun et al. using imidazole as the pore-forming template showed a discharge capacity of 131.7 mA h g−1 at 5 C current density and exhibited good cycle stability even under high-temperature conditions of 120 °C (with a discharge specific capacity of approximately 150 mA h g−1 at 1 C current density) (Fig. 5e). For NIPS, the separator structure can be adjusted by controlling thermodynamic and kinetic factors such as polymer concentration, temperature, solvent, and non-solvent. Generally speaking, one may accurately regulate how quick or slow the polymer solution phases separate by selecting the right solvents and non-solvents based on the mutual diffusion coefficient and non-solvent solubility and further form the porous separator. In 2019, Wang et al. [83] prepared a series of highly porous PBI polymer separators by the NIPS method using water, ethanol, chloroform, and ethyl acetate as non-solvents (as shown in Fig. 6 a). Separators prepared with different non-solvents have different physical properties, among which AP-PBIPE separators prepared with ethyl acetate have the highest mechanical strength. However, the high toxicity and high cost of ethyl acetate limit its large-scale application, and the uneven pore structure also adversely affects the battery performance. In contrast, the EP-PBIPE separator prepared with ethanol as a non-solvent has appropriate mechanical strength and uniform connected pore structure, which can favor the uniform deposition/stripping of lithium ions. As illustrated in Fig. 6(f and g), the prepared cells show excellent rate performance (discharge capacity is still greater than 100 mA h g−1 when the current density is 6 C) and outstanding cycle stability of 1000 cycles. It should be noted that after approximately 600 cycles, the coulombic efficiency of the EP-PBIPE separator was significantly lower than that of the Celgard separator, with a coulombic efficiency below 95%, indicating the failure of LMB. The subsequent stable cycles were due to the excess lithium being able to provide lithium ions almost infinitely, thus artificially enhancing the cycling stability of the LMB and not necessarily indicating the true advantage of the separator. In addition, Wang et al. also demonstrated through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations that the strong interaction between Li+ and the electron-rich imidazole rings of PBI enhanced the Li+ transference number to a value of 0.76, and the mobility of PF− was effectively reduced by the electrostatic repulsion (Fig. 6b–e). These results indicate that there is a substantial potential for the PBI separator to be used in LMBs. In order to further study the multifunctional non-solvent treatment for the preparation of porous separators with adjustable morphology, as shown in Fig. 7 (a), Hussain et al. [84] prepared a series of porous separators using water, ethanol, and isopropanol as non-solvent and N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMAC) as solvent to further study the phase separation behavior of PBI/solvent/non-solvent system, and investigated the influence of coagulant composition on separator morphology and battery performance. Benefiting from the superiority of PBI material itself, the prepared separator has excellent thermal stability and excellent electrolyte wettability (Fig. 7b and c). However, due to the difference in solubility between the solvent and various non-solvents, the pore morphology of the prepared separator is quite variable (Fig. 7d), which significantly alters the electrochemical performance (Fig. 7e–g). The PBI-Water separator prepared with water as a non-solvent has a typically asymmetric finger-like structure. The assembled lithium symmetrical battery showed high overpotential and voltage polarization during lithium deposition/stripping, and a huge irreversible voltage drop occurred at about 34 h. The assembled LiFePO4‖Li battery had a short circuit after two or three cycles, which was attributed to the unstable SEI layer formation and the frequent growth of lithium dendrites. It is worth noting that PBI-EtOH and PBI-IPA prepared with ethanol and isopropanol as non-solvent have uniform spongy porous and three-dimensional grid structures, which can provide uniform lithium-ion transport channels and form smooth current distribution. The assembled lithium symmetric batteries show low voltage polarization and stability of more than 400 h. As illustrated in Fig. 7(f and g), the assembled LiFePO4‖Li cells exhibit higher discharge capacity than commercial PE separators, among which PBI-IPA shows the best rate and cycling performance, which is attributed to the excellent electrochemical interface between PBI-IPA and lithium metal anode and the inhibition of lithium dendrite growth. Hussain et al. also proposed a possible mechanism for the PBI separators to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites during Li deposition/stripping, which will be discussed in Section 4.1.3 in detail. Nanofiber separator prepared by electrospinning has become a research hotspot of high-performance battery separator due to their advantages of high specific surface area, elevated porosity, and uniform pore size distribution. In 2020, Liu et al. [85] investigated the mechanism of the influence of electrospinning OPBI separators on the safety and other properties of batteries and demonstrated the inhibitory effect of fiber OPBI separators on the growth of lithium dendrites (detailed in section 4.1.3). In order to prepare nanofibers with abundant and uniform distributed pores, Liu et al. used dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solvent to dissolve OPBI as an electrospinning solution. The prepared separator consisted of hundreds of nanometers of random nanofibers with a porosity of over 80%, possessing good electrolyte wettability and absorptivity, shown in Fig. 8 (a), much higher than the commercial Celgard2400 separator. The prepared OPBI nanofiber separator has good flexibility (Fig. 8b) and mechanical properties, with an average TS of approximately 20 MPa, which meets the requirements of battery separators. This is mainly due to the rigid aromatic chain structure of OPBI and the dense and cross-linked nanofibers inside the separator, which provide a certain bonding strength. The authors also proposed that the downward trend of TS of the nanofiber membrane is opposite to the trend of diameter change of the fibers. As the concentration of OPBI spinning solution increases, the diameter of the nanofibers increases and the corresponding TS performance decreases. The produced OPBI-8 wt% separator has an electrochemical stability window exceeding 5.75 V at an ambient temperature of 55 °C. Benefiting from the isotropy of the random fibers of the electro-spun separator and the rigid structure of the OPBI material itself, the electro-spun OPBI separator shows excellent thermal dimensional stability, indicating its potential application in high-temperature safe batteries. Due to the highly tortuous and evenly distributed interconnected porous structure of the electro-spun OPBI separator, the assembled symmetric cell has extremely low voltage polarization, and the prepared LiFePO4/Li cell has remarkable cycle stability (94% specific capacity retention rate of 300 cycles) (Fig. 8c). However, the fiber separator prepared by the electrospinning method has high porosity while sacrificing its mechanical properties and the electrospinning method has quite low production efficiency. In order to further enhance the performance and production efficiency of electrospinning PBI separator, Jung et al. [86] first reported the use of α, α-dibromo-p-xylene (DBX) as a cross-linking agent and 4-(chloromethyl) benzoic acid (CMBA) as a modifier to treat the PBI fiber separator prepared by multi-nozzles electrospinning to improve the electrochemical and mechanical properties. Multi-nozzle electrospinning enables the improved productivity and better control of the size and distribution of the fibers (Fig. 8d). The PBI fiber separator before and after crosslinking showed random orientation of fibers (Fig. 8e), and due to the strong chemical network formed by the crosslinking between DBX and PBI chains, the tensile strength (10.77 MPa) and modulus (36.33 MPa) of the crosslinking fiber separator were enhanced (Fig. 8f). Moreover, due to the introduction of Br ions into the structure, the polarization of Br ion reduced the activation barriers and promoted the conduction of lithium ions, and the conductivity of the crosslinked PBI fiber separator was improved. Although the crosslinked separator treated with CMBA modifiers led to the deterioration of its mechanical properties due to its abundant hydrophilic carboxyl functional groups, the crosslinked PBI-CMBA showed a strong affinity for water and electrolyte (the uptake of electrolyte is up to 1151%). However, due to its excessive tortuosity and low conductivity, the cyclic stability of the battery was affected (Fig. 8g). 4.1.2 PBI-based composite separators As mentioned in the previous section, PBI can be prepared into a battery separator by different methods, such as phase conversion and electrospinning. However, the preparation cost of PBI is higher than that of polyolefin, and battery separator prepared by using a single polymer often leads to problems such as reduced transmission efficiency of lithium-ion, unsatisfactory electrochemical performance, and insufficient battery safety when used for an extended period. Therefore, PBI is often combined with other materials to prepare composite separators. Generally speaking, this kind of PBI composite separator can be divided into two categories: PBI as a modified material and PBI as a matrix with other modified materials. In this section, we will discuss the manufacturing process and characteristics of PBI composite separators in detail. A summary of characteristics of the PBI-based composite separators used in LMBs is shown in Table S2. Polyolefin separators, such as PP and PE, hold a dominant potential in the realm of commercial separators, primarily owing to their outstanding mechanical strength and electrochemical stability. However, it is essential to acknowledge that commercial polyolefin separators also face certain challenges, most notably their poor thermal stability and wettability. These limitations can have adverse effects on battery performance and safety. Indeed, modification of polyolefin separators represents an effective approach to address the above challenges. The main method to modify polyolefin separators is to introduce ceramic nanoparticles. While this method effectively enhances the wettability and thermal stability of the polyolefin separator, there exists a concern related to the poor bonding ability between ceramic nanoparticles and the polyolefin material. This weak bonding can result in the detachment of the ceramic coating during battery operation, posing challenges to battery performance and safety. Additionally, the presence of ceramic nanoparticles in the separator can obstruct the pores, hindering ion transport and leading to increased internal resistance within the battery. Consequently, the higher internal resistance adversely affects the power density, impacting the overall efficiency of the battery. The introduction of a polymer layer on the polyolefin separator is another feasible approach to improve the wettability and thermal stability of the separator. PBI has also attracted people's attention because of its extremely high thermal stability and electrolyte wettability. In order to improve the thermal stability of commercial separators, Li et al. [87] reported in 2017 that a simple phase inversion method was used to introduce a thin and porous PBI layer into both surfaces of commercial PE separators to form a sandwich-like composite separator (PBIE) with thermal shutdown function (Fig. 9 a). The addition of PBI coating has significantly increased the thermal stability of commercial PE separator. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the prepared composite PBIE separator can make PE melt and block the pores under the condition of thermal runaway. Due to its high melting point, PBI is retained as a skeleton to avoid contact between the cathode and anode of the battery, considerably enhancing battery safety. Notably, PBI coating essentially does not obstruct the pores of PE intermediate layer, and the cost of a manufactured composite PBIE separator is nearly equivalent to that of a commercial PE separator. Moreover, due to the existence of sponge pores of porous PBI coating and polar groups on the main chain of PBI, the composite PBIE has better electrolyte wettability, higher porosity, and ionic conductivity than the commercial PE separator and has greater potential applications in high power batteries. In 2020, Xue et al. [88] synthesized a novel HBPBI polymer for the first time, combined terephthaldehyde (TAP) as a cross-linking agent with HBPBI, and coated it on the surface of a commercial PE separator by a straightforward dip coating method to form an ultra-thin CHBPBI coating (Fig. 9c and d). As shown in Fig. 9(e), the benzimidazole, amino, and carboxyl groups in CHBPBI greatly improved the electrolyte uptake (90% to 181%), wettability (the contact angle of CHBPBIE was close to 0), and thermal stability of the commercial PE separator. The cross-linking agent TAP endowed HBPBI with additional imidazole groups, which led to the existence of additional active sites in CHBPBIE. The transmission efficiency of lithium ions is significantly increased by the electrostatic interaction between the active sites and the electrolyte (Fig. 9f). The CHBPBI-modified separator, whose ionic conductivity is 10.6 times greater than that of the commercial PE separator, has the greatest ionic conductivity as a result. As shown in Fig. 9(g and h), the battery performance of the CHBPBI separator assembly has been significantly improved (the power capacity at 7 C is increased to 73%, and the retention rate of discharge capacity was 91.1% for 400 cycles at 2 C rate.). Combining PBI materials with other materials is an important way to improve battery performance and safety. For the first time, ethyl cellulose (EC) and PBI were employed as raw materials by Chen et al. [89] to produce a blended polymer gel separator with a novel three-dimensional network-like interconnected porous structure using simple VIPS (Fig. 10 a). Compared with pure EC separators, the introduction of PBI material in PBI/EC blend separators improved the thermal stability of the separator. Infrared thermal imaging tests demonstrated that the blend separator exhibited uniform heat distribution during exposure to high-temperature environments (Fig. 10b). Moreover, the blend separator exhibited significantly higher conductivity (Fig. 10c) and electrochemical performance compared to the commercial PE separator. As shown in Fig. 10(e), these enhancements were attributed to the distinctive three-dimensional porous structure of the PBI/EC separator, which facilitated lithium-ion transport channels, and due to the strong affinity between the amine group on the PBI chain and polar groups such as the hydroxyl group present in the EC fiber and the carbonate electrolyte. The assembled LiCoO2/Li battery still maintains a stable voltage after being kept at 140 °C for 2 h, shown in Fig. 10(d), indicating that the composite separator can be applied to high-security LIBs. Metal-organic framework (MOF) and covalent organic framework (COF) are considered potential materials for improving battery separator systems due to their large specific surface area and porous structure and are also used as nanoparticle filling materials in PBI separators. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), Liu et al. [90] used zirconium-based MOF (UiO-66) with excellent stability as nano-packed particles combined with OPBI and prepared a series of interconnected porous dual-channel cell separators composed of PBI and UiO-66 in coordination with each other by NIPS method. The strong mechanical properties of OPBI overcame the inherent mechanical brittleness of UiO-66. The small nanopore size of UiO-66 and the highly organized porous structure created by the phase inversion process of the OPBI matrix itself make up the distinctive dual channel (Fig. 11b). The highly ordered porous structures can coordinate the uniform distribution of lithium ions, and the introduction of UiO-66 material can capture a significant amount of electrolyte. These promoted orderly ion transport and formed a uniform SEI film, which successfully slowed down the growth of lithium dendrites and significantly enhanced the electrochemical performance. The OPBI composite separator containing 40% UiO-66 has a significantly improved ion conductivity compared to the pristine OPBI separator (Fig. 11c), and the assembled LiFePO4/graphite and LiFePO4/lithium metal batteries show considerable cycle stability and rate performance at both ambient temperature and elevated temperature (Fig. 11d–f). The introduction of MOF is a practical way to enhance the safety and electrochemical performance of the battery. Min et al. [91] also proposed the idea of combining a MOF with OPBI materials to build diversified ion channels. They concentrated their study on enhancing the efficiency of the separator for transporting lithium ions. In this study, ion-modified Zr-based MOF with sulfonic acid groups (UIO-66-S-Li) (Fig. 11g) was combined with OPBI as a nanoparticle filler material using simple phase inversion and physical mixing procedures. The inclusion of UIO-66-S-Li increased the number of active sites for lithium ions and introduced negative charges (–SO3−) to promote interaction with the ions, increasing the ability of the separator to transport lithium ions. At the same time, Min et al. proposed three transport modes for lithium ions in this diverse ion channel membrane (Fig. 11h). The first is the consistent movement of lithium ions via large holes created by the OPBI phase inversion technique; the second is the movement of lithium ions through nanoscale pores inside the actual MOF material; the third involves the passage of lithium ions via the active core of the sulfonic acid groups in MOF. This variety of ion channels not only promotes the uniform distribution of lithium ions but also speeds up the transfer of lithium ions. Additionally, the addition of UiO-66-S-Li aids in the realization of the stability of the interface between the separator and lithium metal. As a result, the composite UiO-66-S-Li@OPBI separator is highly ionic conductive and performs superbly electrochemically (Fig. 11j–m). Furthermore, it can effectively impede lithium dendrite formation. Min et al. [92] also studied in depth the cell separator prepared by introducing a COF into OPBI. COF is a kind of organic crystal material completely composed of light elements through covalent bonding, which has the characteristics of enormous surface area, outstanding thermal stability, and high porosity. In this study, Min et al. used nitrogen-rich COF (SNW-1) (Fig. 12 a) with a large specific surface area and highly crosslinked microporous structure as nanofillers for OPBI separators and developed high-temperature resistant cell separators with excellent thermal stability and flame retardation by simple non-solvent-induced phase separation (Fig. 12c). As shown in Fig. 12(b), the prepared separator exhibits a highly even and continuously open three-dimensional pore structure, with a porosity of 60% for OPBI@COF20, significantly higher than the 41% porosity of PP separator. This enables it to store a larger amount of electrolytes. Furthermore, the separator has excellent flexibility and does not crack when bent (Fig. 12d). The increase in COF content in the composite membrane results in a reduction in its porosity, and the corresponding tensile strength decreases linearly. The lowest tensile strength (15.4 MPa) is observed for OPBI@COF20, but it is still within the required mechanical strength range for Li battery separators. The polar groups in SNW-1 nanoparticles also improve the electrolyte wettability of the separator, making OPBI@COF have good interface compatibility in the electrode/electrolyte interface (Fig. 12e). Notably, due to the high dielectric constant of the SNW-1 polar group, the transmission of charge at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte is prevented, and the composite OPBI@COF20 separator shows an electrochemical stability window of up to 5.5 V vs. Li+/Li (Fig. 12f). The application potential of the composite OPBI@COF separator in high-temperature environment was also studied (Fig. 12g). The capacity retention rate of the prepared half-cell reached 91.8% after 50 cycles at 90 °C, indicating that OPBI@COF composite separator also has a broad application prospect in high-temperature environments. Notably, PBI can be utilized not only as a modified material to enhance the properties of commercial separators and as a matrix to manufacture composite separators by combining with other materials but also as an effective high-temperature adhesive. Sun et al. [93] reported in 2019 that a nanofiber separator with polyimide (PI) as core and PBI as sheath was prepared by self-bonding and self-compression techniques (Fig. 13 a). Due to the unique bonding properties of PBI materials, the prepared PI@PBI fiber separator has a dense and porous structure. The self-bonding and compression techniques significantly improved the tensile strength of the separator (59 MPa). Owing to the polar bond skeleton in the PBI imidazole ring, the rigid structure in PI, and the presence of aromatic groups, the synthesized nanofiber separator has thermal dimensional stability up to 300 °C (Fig. 13b) and excellent wettability. The battery assembled with PI@PBI fiber separator has better battery performance (130.2 mA h g−1 at 5 C) than the Celgard separator (95.4 mA h g−1 at 5 C) and has stable cycle stability even at 120 °C (Fig. 13c). Sun et al. [94] also introduced the thermal shutdown protection mechanism on the basis of the above separator. A novel practical three-layer separator (PBEI) with a thermal shutdown prevention mechanism was constructed by in-situ welding method, specifically using polyether imide fiber separator as the core interlayer and PI@PBI composite separator as the structural support layer (Fig. 13d). The prepared separator has excellent fire resistance and the thermal shutdown protection temperature up to 235 °C; and the mechanical tensile performance has also reached 46.5 MPa; the excellent flexibility of PBEI allows it to regain its original unfolded state after being freely bent, twisted, or folded (Fig. 13e). This is primarily attributed to the compact nanofiber structure and crosslinking structure imparted to the membrane through a thermal compression process. The assembled battery demonstrated excellent magnification capacity (160.2 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C and 132.4 mA h g−1 at 5 C), and it can also have a stable cycling ability at 120 °C (Fig. 13f), which provides a feasible scheme for the preparation of the battery separator with high power and high safety. 4.1.3 Mechanism for dendrites inhibition by PBI/PBI-based composite separators Lithium metal is regarded as the perfect anode for the future secondary battery with high energy density due to its substantial specific capacity (3862 mA h g−1) and low reduction potential (−3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen). Nevertheless, during extended charge-discharge cycles, the formation of lithium dendrites and the presence of unstable SEI layers that are repeatedly formed/destroyed severely restrict the practical use of LMBs, which poses serious risks to their cycle durability and security. Currently, artificial SEI layers [95–97], liquid electrolytes design [98,99], separator engineering [100], and anode substrate design [101–103] are some of the methods frequently employed to prevent the formation of lithium dendrites. In this section, the mechanism of inhibition of dendrite growth by PBI/PBI-based composite separators will be introduced. The uneven deposition of lithium is the major cause of the uneven formation of lithium dendrites. The construction of continuous, uniform Li+ transport channels and the use of active sites to coordinate the diffusion and distribution of lithium ions are two primary strategies for preventing the formation of lithium dendrites through separators. The PBI separator prepared by the NIPS method and electrospinning method has the characteristics of high porosity and uniform pore size distribution, which can mechanically guide the homogeneous deposition/stripping of lithium ions. In addition, the nucleation and electroplating overpotential are decreased, which restricted the formation of lithium dendrites as a result of the good interfacial compatibility between the PBI material itself and the lithium metal anode and electrolyte. Wang et al. [83] showed that an intense conjugated interaction between the electron-rich imidazole ring on the main chain of PBI and lithium ions can promote the dissociation and transportation of lithium ions by using XPS and DFT calculations (as shown in Fig. 6b–e). EIS (Fig. 14 a and b), the performance of the symmetrical battery (Fig. 14c), and SEM photographs of lithium metal before and after a lengthy cycle (Fig. 14d) all demonstrate how significantly improved the lithium-ion migration number (0.76) is and how effectively lithium dendrite growth can be inhibited. The OPBI separator prepared by Liu et al. [85] by the electrospinning method is composed of nanofibers with uniform morphology, random orientation, and an average diameter of hundreds of nanometers. Due to its extremely porous structure and great tortuosity, the pores of the separator may effectively prevent the formation of lithium dendrites and provide low interfacial resistance. Observing the surface morphological changes of the Li metal anode during prolonged cycling allowed researchers to demonstrate the inhibitory impact of the OPBI porous fiber separator on Li dendrite formation (as shown in Fig. 14e). In the process of lithium deposition/stripping, Hussain et al. [84] hypothesized a possible mechanism for limiting the formation of lithium dendrites via a PBI separator (as shown in Fig. 14g). They postulated that the suppression of lithium dendrite growth by a PBI porous separator was the result of its chemical versatility and unique pore morphology. The imidazole ring on the main chain of PBI polymer can trap lithium ions and supply an abundance of lithium-ion adhesion sites, improving the electrolyte affinity and interface compatibility of the separator. In addition, the special spongy, porous structure of PBI can enhance the order of lithium-ion transport, which helps stabilize the formation of the SEI layer and promotes uniform lithium deposition/stripping with the aim of inhibiting lithium dendrite growth. In contrast, the inhomogeneous deposition/stripping of lithium ions on the commercial polyethylene separator leads to the tip strength of the lithium metal surface continuously increasing during cycling, resulting in the formation of sharp and extremely disordered lithium dendrites (Fig. 14f). In addition, the combination of PBI substrate with other materials can facilitate the construction of lithium-ion transport channels and improve the inhibition effect of separator on the growth of lithium dendrites. Liu et al. [90] proposed a possible mechanism for preventing the growth of lithium dendrites by combining OPBI with MOF (UiO-66) (as shown in Fig. 15 a). After introducing UiO-66 into the OPBI framework, a unique interconnected porous network structure with dual transport pathways for lithium ions was formed. This structure combines the highly arranged porous structure inherent in the OPBI matrix with the narrower pore structure composed of UiO-66. The introduction of UiO-66 nanofillers significantly improved lithium-ion conductivity and enhanced the orderliness of lithium-ion transport. Furthermore, the integration of UiO-66 enhanced the interface compatibility between the separator and the lithium metal electrode, effectively preventing the growth of lithium dendrites. On this basis, Min et al. [91] used ion-modified UiO-66-S-Li as nano-filled particles to increase the transport channel of lithium ions traveling via the active center of sulfonic acid groups (as shown in Fig. 11h), which further unified the migration and distribution of lithium ions to achieve uniform lithium deposition/stripping (as shown in Fig. 15b). Min et al. [92] also promoted the construction of lithium-ion transport channels by introducing COF, and the prepared OPBI@COF separator showed a significant inhibition effect on the growth of lithium dendrites (as shown in Fig. 15c). 4.1.4 Summary In this section, we discuss in detail the latest research progress on PBI membranes in lithium metal batteries. We examine the structure and composition of the separator and categorize the PBI membranes into two main types: porous PBI membranes prepared through phase conversion and particle leaching methods and fiber PBI membranes prepared through electrospinning. Additionally, we explore composite separators that consist of PBI as a modified material, along with a matrix and adhesive. Furthermore, we summarize the role of PBI in inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites and present the potential mechanisms involved. The battery separator plays a crucial role in regulating the transport of lithium ions within the battery assembly. By adjusting various preparation methods, such as the composition of solvents and non-solvents in NIPS, vapor exposure time in VIPS, and process parameters in the electrospinning, the pore morphology of the separator can be controlled. An ideal separator should have a rich porous structure (spongy or fibrous), high porosity, and uniform pore size distribution. These characteristics effectively regulate the uniform distribution of lithium ions. The PBI matrix, which contains rich polar groups, exhibits good affinity for the electrolyte and provides a high concentration of active sites for lithium ions. This enhances the ionic conductivity of the separator and improves battery performance. The rigid structure of PBI ensures the high-temperature stability of the separator, enabling the battery to operate in high-temperature environments. When used as a component in a composite separator, PBI can function as a modified coating, adhesive, and separator matrix. This demonstrates the versatility of PBI material and its potential as a lithium battery separator. When combined with other filling materials like ethyl cellulose, MOF, COF, etc., PBI can complementarily enhance the properties of the separator. This includes building an idealized lithium-ion transport channel and improving the electrolyte wettability, ionic conductivity, and thermal stability of the separator. The inhibitory effect of the PBI membrane on the growth of lithium dendrites is attributed to its uniform porous morphology and the chemical multi-functionality of PBI itself. The classical separator preparation methods can adjust the pore morphology, while the addition of modified nanomaterials can further construct an idealized lithium-ion transport channel and improve the order of lithium-ion transport. These factors promote the formation of a stable SEI layer, facilitate uniform lithium deposition/stripping, and enhance the inhibition of lithium dendrite growth. The research progress of PBI in lithium metal batteries has indeed demonstrated its potential as a high-performance battery separator. However, there are still several challenging problems that need to be addressed. (1) To adapt to the future application market of high-performance battery separators, it is crucial to understand the production cost of PBI separators further. Striking a balance between performance and economy is necessary. (2) The pore morphology of the separator significantly affects the performance of the battery. It is essential to identify the optimal pore morphology from various morphologies generated by different preparation methods. (3) Expanding the application of PBI membranes requires considering harsh working environments, such as high temperatures and high-current operations. (4) The current research on PBI-based composite membranes is relatively limited compared to other polymer-based composite membranes (e.g., PVDF, PI). Further research is needed to explore the combination of PBI with other filling materials, like two-dimensional porous nanomaterials, and new composite technologies, such as ultra-thin surface coatings. 4.2 Lithium-sulfur batteries Li-S batteries have received a great deal of interest because of their high energy density (up to 2567 Wh kg−1), high theoretical specific capacity (1672 Wh kg−1), and environmentally beneficial characteristics. However, the inevitable problems of Li-S batteries, such as the soluble polysulfide (PS) shuttling effect and the growth of lithium dendrites, limit their commercial development. The most effective method currently being used to combat the polysulfide shuttle effect is the employment of polar materials to capture polysulfides and reduce their diffusion flux [104,105]. PBI has been utilized extensively in LSBs and has a clear inhibitory impact on the formation of dendrites. Additionally, the abundant nitrogen-containing functional groups of PBI also have significant potential in Li-S batteries because they can efficiently adsorb PS and inhibit the shuttling of polysulfides. Li et al. [35] reported in 2016 that modified polybenzimidazole (mPBI) (as shown in Fig. 16 a) was used as the binder for sulfur cathode in Li-sulfur batteries and as a functional separator. The introduction of mPBI effectively inhibited the dissolution and diffusion effects of polysulfide. On the one hand, as a binder, it preserved the integrity of the electrode and increased the mechanical strength of the sulfur cathode. The functional groups on the mPBI polymer can have rich chemical interactions with PS, providing effective PS adsorption capacity to inhibit the loss of active sulfur (Fig. 16b). On the other hand, as a functional separator, mPBI formed a barrier layer with ion-selective properties, which effectively prevented the migration of PS and further inhibited its shuttle effect (Fig. 16c). Under the dual action of mPBI, as shown in Fig. 16(d), the assembled Li-S battery still has excellent battery performance after 500 cycles at 0.2 C (discharge capacity = 750 mA h g−1, decay ratio per cycle = 0.08%). Hussain et al. [106] reported in 2020 that a nanoporous PBI separator prepared by a simple and convenient phase conversion method was applied to Li-S batteries. Similar to his previous work, lithium-symmetric batteries assembled by the prepared PBI separator also had good lithium deposition/stripping performance under high current density, and the pores with nano-size structures can significantly inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites (as shown in Fig. 17 a and b). Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 17(c and d), calculations based on reduced density gradient (RDG) and DFT calculations showed that the nitrogen (N) in the imidazole ring on the main chain of PBI can produce rich chemical interactions with polysulfide PS. This suggests that the PBI separator has a strong adsorption effect on PS, which can effectively reduce the issue of continuous polysulfide shuttling. As illustrated in Fig. 17(e and f), the assembled Li-S coin batteries showed excellent rate performance (2 C = 780 mA h g−1) and considerable cycle stability (discharge capacity of 523 mA h g−1 after 400 cycles at 0.5 C). It also has a high discharge capacity of 744 mA h g−1 (0.1 C 100 cycles) even at a high sulfur load of 3 mg cm−2, as shown in Fig. 17(g). 4.3 Solid-state batteries The electrolyte in typical LIBs is mostly composed of lithium salts that have been dissolved in organic ester/ether solvents. For instance, a commercial lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) electrolyte is made of LiPF6 dissolved in an organic carbonate mixture consisting of EC, dimethyl carbonate (DMC), and methyl carbonate (EMC). However, due to the intense volatility and flammability of these substances, it is simple for the heat produced inside the battery to set the electrolyte ablaze and cause an explosion under adverse operating circumstances, causing a major safety concern. In addition, when lithium metal is used as the anode, its ultra-high reactive activity is prone to having side reactions with electrolytes; lithium dendrite growth punctures the separator and leads to a short circuit. In general, batteries composed of organic electrolytes sacrifice their safety while increasing their energy density. In contrast, solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) promise to improve both the energy density and safety performance of batteries. SSEs should be employed as a barrier to avoid contact between the anode and cathode of batteries as well as the carrier of lithium-ion transport channels, and they should have strong ionic conductivity, electronic insulation, good mechanical qualities, outstanding flame retardancy, and other desirable features. SSEs may be broadly devided into two categories: all-solid electrolytes and gel polymer electrolytes (GPE). All-solid electrolytes can then be further separated into solid inorganic electrolytes (SIEs) and solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs). This section will go into great depth on how PBI has lately been utilized with various kinds of solid-state electrolytes. 4.3.1 Application of PBI in solid polymer electrolytes The SPEs are primarily constituted of polymer matrix and lithium salt, and they have become a hot topic of research due to their good flexibility, low interface resistance, easy processability, and effective inhibition of lithium dendrite growth. Among the polymers used in SPEs, polyethylene oxide (PEO) has been considered as an ideal polymer matrix used in SPEs due to its good lithium-ion solubility, strong lithium metal reduction resistance, lightweight, and low cost. However, the high crystallinity of the PEO at ambient temperature results in low ionic conductivity (10−7–10−5 S cm−1 at 25 °C). Although increasing the temperature to the PEO melting point (65 °C) can improve its ionic conductivity, it also sacrifices its thermal dimensional stability and mechanical strength, which somewhat restricts their widespread application [107–109]. In this case, different strategies are designed for such problems, including the construction of the cross-linked network structures [110,111], the addition of organic plasticizers or inorganic filler [112,113], polymer copolymerization [114], “polymer in salt” [115], etc. Among the polymer copolymerization has been proven to be a method of strong scalability and a simple process. The rigid structure containing imidazole rings and abundant polar functional groups on the main chain of aromatic polybenzimidazole PBI is expected to enhance the thermal stability, ionic conductivity, and mechanical strength of SPEs. Additionally, its proton donor (–NH–) can form abundant hydrogen bonds with other polymer chains, improve compatibility, and reduce the crystallinity of polymers; its proton acceptor (–N=) can also accelerate the decomposition of lithium salts through electrostatic interactions and increase the number of lithium-ion migration. Therefore, PBI has great application potential in PEO-based SSEs. In 2022, in response to the drawbacks of PEO solid polymer electrolyte, which include issues like crystallization, low ionic conductivity, poor mechanical properties, and flammability, Zhang et al. [116] proposed a secure, high-performance SPE prepared by a straightforward solution blending method to combine polybenzimidazole PBI with PEO as shown in Fig. 18 (a). Zhang et al. demonstrated that the imidazole rings of PBI act as hydrogen bond donors, forming numerous hydrogen bonds with the ether groups present in PEO, which effectively inhibited the crystallization of PEO (as shown in Fig. 18b). The calculated crystallinity of the SPE showed a significant reduction when the PBI addition reached 20%, with the crystallinity dropping to only 1.24%. This decrease in crystallinity promotes the movement of polymer chains within the amorphous segment, consequently enhancing the conductivity of lithium ions. Furthermore, the abundant N atoms in PBI contribute to the dissociation of lithium salt LiTFSi through electrostatic action, which greatly improves the ionic conductivity (as shown in Fig. 18c). It is precisely due to the rich hydrogen bonding formed between PBI and PEO that the 20% PBI/PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte exhibits a modulus and tensile strength of 28.3 and 2.97 MPa (as shown in Fig. 18d), respectively, and its elongation at break reaches 109%. The high modulus performance effectively prevents the penetration of lithium dendrites. Moreover, the thermal stability of PBI-added SPEs is greatly improved compared to SPEs without PBI, as shown in Fig. 18(e). In 2023, Zou et al. [117] focused their research strategy on modified PEO on “polymer in salt”, which means that the concentration of lithium salt in solid polymer electrolyte is increased to more than 50%. Such salt-rich SPEs may significantly boost charge carrier concentrations and decrease polymer matrix crystallinity, which enhances overall ionic conductivity and lithium-ion mobility. However, the significant decrease of crystallinity will lead to the decrease of mechanical properties of SPEs, and the effect of inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites is not ideal. Therefore, Zou et al. used PBI as a physical reinforcement to add to the PEO-based salt-pack polymer electrolyte. The addition of PBI formed a stable mechanical framework and gave the electrolyte a stable structure. The mechanism diagram is shown in Fig. 18(f). The electrostatic distribution of PBI indicated that the surface of the imidazole ring in the chain is negatively charged, and the –NH– and –N= groups on both sides are positively and negatively charged, respectively, and can act as proton donors and proton acceptors, respectively. On the one hand, the –NH– groups can form abundant strong hydrogen bonds with its own PBI chain segment or with the –N= of other PBI chain segments, ensuring that the rigid chain structure of PBI is tightly stacked. On the other hand, the –NH– groups can also produce hydrogen bonds with the negatively charged ether groups of PEO to ensure the structural stability of the electrolyte. Therefore, SPEs have adequate mechanical strength to withstand the formation of lithium dendrites thanks to the rich rigid chain structure of PBI and the tight hydrogen connection created between the imidazole ring of PBI and the PEO polymer. Zou et al. also further revealed the strong interaction between PBI, PEO, and lithium salt LiClO4 through Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and confirmed the formation of hydrogen bonds between the –NH– group on the imidazole ring of PBI and the ether group on the PEO chain and the O atom in ClO4 −. Combined with DFT calculation, it is shown that there is a force between the proton acceptor (–N= ) on the PBI imidazole ring and Li+, which can boost the dissociation of lithium salt through electrostatic interaction to obtain a higher concentration of free lithium ions. The hydrogen bond formed by the –NH– group and ClO4 − also effectively reduces the Li–O binding energy. Under the synergistic action of the two groups on the PBI imidazole ring, lithium ions can be easily dissociated from lithium salts, and the generation of hydrogen bonds can effectively inhibit the movement of inhibitory anions to achieve a large lithium-ion transfer number (0.639), promoting the homogeneous deposition of lithium ions and effectively inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites (as shown in Fig. 18g). The assembled LMB showed improved performance (Fig. 18h), and the LiNi0.88Co0.09Mn0.03O2 (NCM88) soft-pack battery assembled with PBI-PEO-2Li also demonstrated its flexibility and safety in practical applications (as shown in Fig. 18i and j). In addition to PEO, the polar semi-crystalline polymer polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) has the advantages of a small van der Waals radius (1.32 Å), strong –C–F– electron-withdrawing group, excellent mechanical properties, and chemical stability, which has good prospects for development. However, its poor thermal stability also has certain hidden dangers [118,119]. For this reason, Chen et al. [120] designed a flame-retardant SPE in 2022 by introducing flame-retardant polybenzimidazole PBI into α-phase PVDF matrix (Fig. 19 a). Similar to the above studies, Chen et al. showed through electrostatic potential analysis that abundant proton donors (–NH–) and proton acceptors (–N=) in the PBI imidazole ring not only contribute to the formation of dense and stable hydrogen bonds (as shown in Fig. 19b, –NH– in PBI is bonded to –C–F– in PVDF), which enabled the electrolyte to withstand chemical structure changes at extreme temperatures, and also help to improve the dissociation of Li+ and hinder the movement of TFSI−, increasing the lithium ion migration number (0.49). Phase field simulation and DFT calculation further revealed the mechanism of inhibition of lithium dendrite growth by PBI/PVDF/LiTFSI SPE. The negatively charged imidazole rings of PBI and LiTFSI have large adsorption energy, which can share overlapping electron density with lithium metal anodes. The robust adsorption among PBI, LiTFSi, and lithium metal can accelerate the conduction of lithium ions, thus accelerating the conductivity of lithium ions at room temperature. The uniform electric field distribution indicated uniform deposition of lithium ions, which effectively inhibited the growth of lithium dendrites (as shown in Fig. 19c–f). As shown in Fig. 19(g), the LiFePO4 battery assembled by the PBI/PVDF/LiTFSI SPE can provide a high discharge capacity of 127 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.15 mA cm−2 and maintain a discharge capacity of 111.2 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles (87.5% capacity retention rate). More importantly, Chen et al. revealed the unique fire protection mechanism of PBI/PVDF/LiTFSI SPE, simulated the flame retardancy mechanism of PBI/PVDF structure evolution under high-temperature environment by calculating molecular dynamics (AIMD), and demonstrated that PBI would undergo dehydrogenation and fluorination reactions under high-temperature environment, resulting in the conversion of part of PVDF into PTEE flame-retardant segments (Fig. 19h). Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) results showed that the benzimidazole chains in PBI were decomposed into highly graphitized carbon layers on PVDF at high temperatures, further blocking heat and oxygen and enhancing the fire protection function of SPE (Fig. 19i). 4.3.2 Application of PBI in gel polymer electrolytes Gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs), whose state is between all-solid electrolytes and liquid electrolytes, are considered to be the most probable electrolytes for next-generation commercial LIBs due to their higher ionic conductivity (10−4–10−3 S m−1), excellent electrode affinity, and lower leakage potential than all-solid electrolytes. Like SPEs, the current research on various GPEs mainly focuses on polymers such as PEO and PVDF. However, one of the ongoing problems with GPE derived from a single polymer matrix is its low ionic conductivity and poor heat stability. Polymer cross-linking is frequently employed to decrease the content of crystalline phases and improve ionic conductivity in order to address the aforementioned issues. However, simple polymer copolymerization or blending may result in poor battery interface compatibility, a decrease in mechanical strength, and other adverse reactions. In order to deal with those issues, as shown in Fig. 20 (a and b), Xue et al. [121] constructed a polymer lithium-ion conduction system (OPBI) and a three-dimensional ion transport system (γ-LiAlO2) by simple solution casting method and introduced them into a PVDF-HFP-based GPE to simultaneously improve its compatibility, ionic conductivity, and thermal stability. Similar to the above-mentioned research by Chen et al. [120], the introduction of OPBI can promote the dissociation of lithium salts and improve ionic conductivity while forming hydrogen bonds with –F– atoms in PVDF to improve compatibility and thermal stability. Many oxide ion vacancies in the unique LiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedral three-dimensional lattice structure of γ-LiAlO2can serve as lithium-ion transport sites (as shown in Fig. 20c and d), ensuring good interface stability. Additionally, modified γ-LiAlO2 (PHOP-LAO) was produced by treating with hyperbranched polybenzimidazole (HBPBI), which increased the performance of GPE and increased the lithium-ion migration number to 0.84. The assembled battery had a good rate and cycle ability (as shown in Fig. 20e and f, the capacity retention rate was 85% after 500 cycles at 2 C rate, and the capacity retention rate was 77% of the initial capacity at 10 C rate at 50 °C). 4.3.3 Application of PBI in single ion conducting polymer electrolytes The traditional solid polymer electrolyte is dual-ion conductors with low lithium-ion migration numbers (t Li+<0.4). Anions and cations move together during long-term battery cycling, and anions accumulate continuously on the anode. This causes concentration polarization, which continuously consumes lithium ions at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte and further promotes the growth of lithium dendrites. In contrast, single ion conducting polymer electrolytes (SIPEs) are able to anchor charge-delocalized anionic groups to the polymer backbone, only allowing the movement of lithium cations, so that it has an extremely high lithium-ion migration number (t Li+ is close to 1), which effectively reduces the concentration polarization phenomenon and effectively inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites. The charge-delocalized anionic groups anchored on the main chain of polymerization mainly include disulfonamide (N(SO2–)− 2) and sp 3 boron (B(O–)− 4). Based on the former, in 2021, Du et al. [122] proposed to chemically graft PBI with lithium propanesulfonyl (trifluoromethyl sulfonyl) imide (LiPSTFSI) by nucleophilic substitution (PBI-g-LiPSTFSI) (as shown in Fig. 21 a). The strong dipole-dipole force provided by PBI helps to produce a flexible and homogeneous self-supporting single-ion polymer electrolyte separator (Fig. 21b). The electrolyte separator has exceptional mechanical strength and thermal stability owing to the rigid polymer chains of PBI and its formidable aromatic π–π bond stacking. It is worth noting that Du et al. studied the mechanical properties changes of PBI-g-LiPSTFSI separators after drying and immersion in the electrolyte. The dried membranes exhibited a maximum tensile strength of up to 60.1 MPa due to the presence of strong aromatic π–π bonding, and the elongation at break was 8.94%. However, after immersion in the electrolyte, the polar organic carbonates in the electrolyte weakened the interaction of the aromatic π–π bonds, resulting in a maximum tensile strength of only one-fifth of the dried state (14.5 MPa), but the elongation at break was increased to 29%. This indicates an improvement in elasticity at the expense of sacrificing toughness (as shown in Fig. 21d). The prepared SIPE has a high lithium-ion migration number of 0.91, and the assembled lithium symmetric battery can withstand a long-term constant current cycle of 1000 h at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 (as shown in Fig. 21c), which proved that PBI-g-LiPSTFSI can prevent concentration polarization and effectively inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. However, SIPE based on disulfamide often involves complex processes such as precursor synthesis, monomer polymerization, and anionic lithiation. By contrast, the SIPE produced by sp 3 boron is simple, convenient, and low-cost, and the inherent flame retardation of boron is also conducive to improving battery safety. In 2021, Zhang et al. [37] proposed a fully aromatic sp 3 boron-based SIPE (PO-PBSB), as shown in Fig. 21(e), which was composed of a fully aromatic polybenzimidazole (PBI) and lithium poly 4,4′-dihydroxydiphenyl sulfone borate (Li-PSB).
