The preparation method of non-solvent-induced phase separation made the separator have highly continuous lithium-ion transport channels. The O=S=O groups in Li-PSB and the strong electrolyte affinity of PBI-rich imidazole rings as well as the presence of sp 3 boron anions made PO-PBSB separator exhibit a high ion conductivity of 0.62 mS cm−1 (Fig. 21f) and a high lithium-ion migration number of 0.85, which are extremely beneficial to suppressing concentration polarization and continuous consumption of anions, thereby inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites shown in Fig. 21(h). As shown in Fig. 21(g), the assembled lithium symmetric battery can withstand the long-term constant current cycles for 2000 h at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2, showing good development prospects. 4.3.4 Summary This section provides a detailed discussion of the application of PBI in solid electrolytes. Solid electrolytes, compared to conventional LIBs, have the potential to improve energy density and safety performance. Polymer-based solid electrolytes encompass SPEs and GPEs, with commonly used polymers being PEO and PVDF. However, the high crystallinity of PEO-based solid polymer electrolytes at room temperature leads to low ionic conductivity, while the poor thermal stability of PVDF-based solid polymer electrolytes limits their further development. These challenges can be effectively addressed by incorporating other polymers to achieve polymer copolymerization, blending, and cross-linking. Aromatic polybenzimidazole, with abundant imidazole rings and polar functional groups on the PBI main chain, emerges as a promising solution. It significantly enhances the thermal stability, ionic conductivity, and mechanical strength of the electrolyte. Moreover, the plentiful proton donor (–NH–) on the PBI imidazole ring can form strong hydrogen bonds with other polymer chains (such as PEO), thereby reducing the overall crystallinity of the polymer. The proton acceptor (–N=) also facilitates electrostatic interaction with lithium ions, leading to the accelerated decomposition of lithium salts and a subsequent increase in the lithium-ion migration number within the electrolyte. Additionally, PBI offers anchoring sites for charge-delocalized anion groups in single ion conductive polymer electrolytes, effectively inhibiting anion movement and mitigating the occurrence of concentration polarization. Consequently, PBI exhibits a high lithium-ion migration number (t Li + is close to 1). 5 Summary With the continuous development of lithium battery storage technology, addressing the challenges of high energy density and high safety has become crucial. Consequently, the development strategy employed for battery separators plays a crucial role in the progress of next-generation lithium batteries. An ideal battery separator should satisfy the following requirements: (1) possessing long-term electrochemical stability to ensure the durability of the battery over time; (2) exhibiting an outstanding affinity for electrolytes and excellent wetting properties to enhance its electrochemical performance; (3) demonstrating good thermal stability to ensure the normal operation of the battery in high-temperature environments; (4) Having sufficient mechanical strength to prevent lithium dendrite growth from piercing the separator; (5) cost-effective and easily manufactured for large-scale production. As currently, only a few separators simultaneously fulfill all these requirements. PBI-based battery separators have shown tremendous potential in addressing crucial issues such as suppressed lithium dendrite growth, mitigated sulfur shuttle effect, and improved solid-state battery conductivity. These achievements can be attributed to their exceptional mechanical, thermal, and chemical stability. This article presents a comprehensive overview of the latest research progress on the utilization of PBI separators in various types of lithium batteries, including lithium-metal batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries, and solid-state batteries. The physical and electrochemical properties of different PBI separators, prepared through various fabrication methods, are summarized. For instance, the NIPS method enables the production of tunable porous membranes with finger-like or sponge-like structures, while electrospinning enables the creation of fiber separators with high specific surface areas and porosity. The incorporation of PBI as a modified material in combination with commercial separators or as an adhesive with other polymers endows the separators with favorable physical and electrochemical properties. Furthermore, incorporating research hotspots in the field of materials such as MOF and COF as additives into the PBI matrix can facilitate the formation of lithium-ion transport pathways and enhance the orderliness of lithium ions, thereby improving the performance of PBI membranes. The uniform porous morphology of PBI-based membranes, along with their chemical multifunctionality, exhibits a noticeable inhibition effect on lithium dendrite growth. Additionally, the abundant nitrogen groups on the imidazole rings of the PBI backbone can strongly adsorb PS in lithium-sulfur batteries, effectively reducing the ongoing shuttle effect of polysulfides. In solid-state batteries, PBI also demonstrates its significant advantages. By blending with commonly used polymers such as PEO and PVDF in current solid-state polymer electrolytes, PBI can effectively compensate for their limitations, such as poor thermal stability, low ion conductivity, and low ion migration number. On the one hand, the presence of polar functional groups and imidazole rings on the PBI backbone improves the thermal stability, ion conductivity, and mechanical strength of the electrolyte. On the other hand, the abundant proton donor (–NH–) and proton acceptor (–N=) groups in PBI can form strong and abundant hydrogen bonds with other polymers, reducing the crystallinity of the polymer, enhancing the structural stability of the electrolyte, and improving the mechanical properties. This simultaneously promotes the dissociation of lithium salts, further enhancing the lithium-ion migration in the electrolyte. In single-ion conductive polymer electrolytes, PBI can also provide anchoring sites for charge-delocalized anions, such as disulfonamide (N(SO2–)− 2) and sp 3 boron (B(O–)− 4), effectively avoiding the occurrence of concentration polarization phenomena. 6 Future directions As previously mentioned, although PBI-based separators exhibit numerous potential advantages for lithium batteries, research in this area is still at an early stage. There are several challenges and technical issues that must be addressed before these separators can be commercialized. Further in-depth research is necessary to overcome these challenges and explore their broader application, and the following perspectives should be considered for future research and development (as shown in Fig. 22 ). (1) Updating and developing manufacturing techniques: the core of membrane manufacturing lies in pore formation, which requires high consistency. As mentioned in Section 3, the current methods commonly used for preparing separators include phase inversion and electrospinning. However, these methods have certain drawbacks. The production process of phase inversion-based separators is influenced by various external factors, such as air humidity, temperature, solution concentration, and scraper parameters. These factors necessitate strict control of the production environment. On the other hand, electrospinning suffers from high production costs and low efficiency, which hinder its widespread adoption. As an engineering-grade high-performance polymer, PBI incurs higher costs compared to traditional separator materials. In order to achieve large-scale industrial production, cost-effective and scalable manufacturing processes are crucial for separator development based on PBI. Therefore, optimizing manufacturing techniques and exploring innovative preparation methods such as electrophoretic deposition (EPD) and plasma polymerization are imperative. These approaches ensure separator consistency, reduce production costs, and achieve a balance between performance and economy. (2) Research on thin PBI separators and their advanced functions: most research efforts in the field primarily focus on thicker PBI separators, typically above 25 μm. However, investigating PBI-based separators with thicknesses below 15 μm aligns more closely with the future direction of separator development. Thin separators offer several advantages, including reduced internal resistance, increased energy density, and lower costs. While reducing the thickness of separators may pose challenges to mechanical strength, puncture resistance, battery safety, and reliability, these concerns can be mitigated by introducing ultra-thin functional coatings (less than 1 μm) and other relevant technologies. By carefully designing and testing the separators, it is possible to balance achieving thinness and maintaining satisfactory mechanical properties. Researching thin PBI-based separators and developing techniques to address their mechanical limitations will significantly enhance the overall performance, energy efficiency, and safety of lithium batteries. Furthermore, we are no longer satisfied with separators solely serving the purpose of suppressing lithium dendrite growth, improving substrate/separator interfaces, and limiting anion migration. We aim to further develop advanced functionalities of the separator. For instance, integrating the electrode and separator effectively eliminates contact resistance between the separator and electrode and enhances ion transport, thus reducing internal resistance within the battery. Another area of interest is the development of self-healing separators that can automatically repair cracks or gaps, thereby enhancing battery safety and lifespan. Additionally, achieving in-situ solidification of the separator is desirable to increase the energy density and flexibility of the battery. Developing these advanced separator functionalities will further enhance the compatibility and expand the application market of PBI separators. (3) Exploring compatibility with other battery components: to align the research on PBI separators with their future commercial applications, it is crucial to explore the compatibility of PBI with other battery components. For instance, investigating the role of thin lithium foils (less than 50 μm) in inhibiting dendrite growth when combined with PBI separators is essential. Using thick lithium foils (250 μm or even more significant) artificially enhances the cycling performance of the battery by continuously replenishing lithium, which does not accurately reflect the real cycling efficiency under practical usage conditions. Employing a limited and controlled amount of lithium enables a more realistic assessment of PBI separator performance for high-energy-density commercial designs. Moreover, incorporating more advanced characterization techniques will contribute to a better understanding and analysis of the lithium-ion transport mechanism on PBI-based separators. This approach will facilitate the establishment of a more rational and precise mechanism for inhibiting lithium dendrite formation. By adopting these advanced characterization techniques, researchers can comprehensively understand the separator behavior and facilitate the design of improved separators tailored to specific battery chemistries and applications. (4) Environmental impact: as with any new technology, researchers must prioritize assessing their environmental impact and ensure that these separators are environmentally friendly. It is crucial for researchers to be committed to using sustainable materials and adopting eco-friendly production processes in order to minimize their ecological footprint. By prioritizing the evaluation of environmental impacts and implementing sustainable practices, the acceptance and adoption of PBI-based separators can be enhanced in the market and contribute to the overall advancement of environmentally conscious battery technologies. coredata.dc:description: With the rapid development of portable technology, lithium batteries have emerged as potential candidates for high-performance energy storage systems owing to their high energy density and cycling stability. Among the key components of a lithium battery system, the separator plays a critical role as it directly influences the battery performance benchmark (cycling performance and safety). However, traditional polyolefin separators (polypropylene/polyethylene) are unable to meet the demands of high-performance and safer battery systems due to their poor electrolyte compatibility, thermal runaways, and ultimate growth of dendrites. In contrast, membranes fabricated using polybenzimidazole (PBI) exhibit excellent electrolyte wettability and outstanding thermal dimensional stability, thus holding great potential as separators for high-performance and high-safety batteries. In this paper, we present a comprehensive review of the general requirements for separators, synthesis technology for separators, and research trends focusing PBI membranes in lithium batteries to alleviate the current commercial challenges faced by conventional polyolefin separators. In addition, we discuss the future development direction for PBI battery separators by considering various factors such as production cost, ecological footprint, preparation technology, and battery component compatibility. By exploring these perspectives, we aim to promote the continued application and exploration of PBI-based materials to advance lithium battery technology.
